section.h4: When are children going to be allowed to go back to school?
section.p: North Carolina's public schools will remain closed through May 15, per Executive Order 120.Â View the video message discussingÂ considerations on a date students may return to school and the process state education leaders used to determine that date.
section.h4: While schools are closed, are all children continuing their classwork remotely?
section.p: Remote learning is strongly encouraged across the state for all NC public schoolÂ students to support continued student growth and well-being during this publicÂ health crisis.Â NCDPI encourages LEAs/Charters to provide a variety of remote learning opportunities toÂ engage all students, continue academic growth, and respond to social and emotionalÂ needs. View the video message discussing why it's important for students to complete school work assigned by teachers.Â Contact your local school district or charter school leaders for additional information on what remote learning opportunities they are able to provide to students.
section.h4: What resources are available to help my child learn?
section.p: View this video message sharingÂ guidance on where to find online resources to help teachers and parents provide instruction to students.
section.h4: What do I do if I donâ€™t have a computer at home for my child?Â What do I do if I canâ€™t access the internet?
section.p: View the video message on options for families who donâ€™t have online access, guidance on who to ask for assistance and a discussion about innovative and creative ways school and community organizations are working together to bring computers and internet access to families.
section.h4: Will my child be graded on the work or lessons happening while school is closed?
section.p: View this video message discussingÂ how grading will shift emphasis for the remainder of the year to supporting student progress and communicating feedback to students and their families.
section.h4: Will kids still be taking end of year assessments? State assessments?
section.p: View the video message sharingÂ updates on actions taken by NCDPI and the State Board of Education for year-end assessments for the 2019-20 school year.
section.h4: My child has an IEP. What supports are being put into place for them?
section.p: View this video message sharingÂ guidance on how schools, districts and the state will support parents with children who have Individualized Learning Plans (IEP)
section.h4: My child is a senior. Will they still be graduating this year?
section.p: View the video message on how the statewide school closure due to COVID-19 will impact seniors scheduled to graduate this spring.
section.h4: My child was scheduled to take the SATs, PSATs, AP Test, etc. Will this assessment be rescheduled?
section.p: Students and families should visit the websites for each of these services to get the most up-to-date information. SAT, ACT, and AP testing have all provided recent updates.Â
section.h4: How will my childâ€™s grades or assessments be transferred to their college?
section.p: All of NCDPI's student data practices and protocols are still fully functioning. Student transcripts should be produced and available for both the student and the colleges or universities students direct their transcripts to at the conclusion of this school year. Students and families should follow the direction of their local school district or charter school for obtaining official transcripts.
section.h4: Will my child move up to the nextÂ grade at the end of this year?
section.p: There have been some rumors circulating online that all students in NC would repeat the grade they are in next year. That isÂ not true. Principals may retain an individual student, as they always have had the authority to do, if the student does not meet school or district determined requirements for promotion. There has not been any statewide direction altering promotion and retention policies at this time; NCDPI has advised schools to continue to follow best practices to ensure student success.

div.a: Department of Health & Human Services Information

section.h2: Department of Health & Human Services Information
section.h4: All North Carolinians can prepare for COVID-19 by getting the latest information directly from reliable sources. The COVID-19 outbreak has been accompanied by aÂ flood of misinformation from unreliable sources. Be thoughtful about what you read or hear about the virus and make sure you are separating rumor from fact before you act.
section.p: Get information from reliable sourcesÂ and review frequently asked questions addressed by NC's Department of Health and Human Services.

section.h4: My child used to get breakfast, lunch, and/or snack from their school. Can they still get a school meal?
section.p: Yes, school meals are still being provided to children who previously qualified to receive a school breakfast, lunch, and/or supper. These meals can be picked-up at designated meal sites.Â View this video message discussingÂ resources to help parents find locations across the state that are serving school meals.

School-based meal sites are generally serving breakfast and lunch. Please contact your local school district for more information, or follow the instructions below to text FOODNC to 877-877 to find nearby meal sites and serving times.
section.h4: How can I find out where I can pick-up a meal for my child?
section.p: To locate a meal site near you, text FOODNC to 877-877. You will be asked to enter your address. You will receive a text back with the location of the closest meal sites and serving times. You can also call 2-1-1 to speak with an operator 24/7 who can help locate meal sites and other resources.
section.h4: Do I need to bring anything to prove my child qualifies for a free meal?
section.p: No, you do not need to bring anything to prove your child qualifies for a free meal. Also, you do not need to bring your child with you to pickup a meal for your child.

section.h4: With schools closed, does my childâ€™s teacher still have a job?
section.p: The State Board of Education has issued guidance to local school districts and charter schools that all staff remain in work status and are eligible to be paid.
section.h4: Will my child return to the same teacher/class when school reopens?
section.p: Governor Cooper's Executive Order 120 closes K-12 public schools statewide through May 15. You can expect more communication from your local school district or charter school with information on plans to return to school.
section.h4: If my child had multiple teachers across different subjects, how can they best keep in touch with all of them?
section.p: Many school districts and charters are going above and beyond in trying to keep open lines of communication from staff to parents and families. And, families are all facing many challenges as theyÂ cope with this extended school closure. Email is often the best contact for teachers but families should also feel free toÂ reach out to your local school by phone and to keep informed through school or district websites and social media pages.Â
